review.title: Discretization of Temporal Data: A Survey
review.abstract: In real world, the huge amount of temporal data is to be processed in many application areas such as scientific, financial, network monitoring, sensor data analysis. Data mining techniques are primarily oriented to handle discrete features. In the case of temporal data the time plays an important role on the characteristics of data. To consider this effect, the data discretization techniques have to consider the time while processing to resolve the issue by finding the intervals of data which are more concise and precise with respect to time. Here, this research is reviewing different data discretization techniques used in temporal data applications according to the inclusion or exclusion of: class label, temporal order of the data and handling of stream data to open the research direction for temporal data discretization to improve the performance of data mining technique.

metadata.title: Discretization of Temporal Data: A Survey

sections.text: In many fields of application, such as science, finance, network monitoring, sensor data analysis. Data mining techniques are primarily designed to handle discrete characteristics. In the case of temporal data, time plays an important role in the characteristics of data. In order to take this effect into account, the discretization techniques used in data processing must take into account the time needed to solve the problem by finding the time more precise and more precise data intervals. This research examines various discretization techniques used in applications of temporal data to improve the performance of data mining technology.

sections.heading: Keywords— Temporal data, Discretization, Supervised, Incremental, Nonparametric
sections.text: This year, it is as far as ever in the history of the city, where it is as far as never before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: B. Supervised Discretization
sections.text: There are numbers of supervised discreditation on the basis of entropy-interested readers with [2], [3] but here the methods based on clustering [15] and on class-attribute continuity coefficients [16] are discussed, how they look in terms of temporal characteristics and also in terms of class information.This method takes advantage of class-label and natural grouping, and is based on clusters discrediting the data with the knowledge of both classes and clusters. [15] In this method, two cluster algorithms are used - that is, cluster-cluster approach with euphoria-distance-metric-metric discrediting.

sections.heading: III. SUMMARY AND FUTURE SCOPE
sections.text: The discretization of data plays an important role in data pre-processing before applying a set of data mining algorithms to the real evaluated data sets. Here briefly the necessity of discretization with the idea and disadvantages of some methods under supervised or unsupervised category for the temporal data. The analysis is based on various questions of discretization that show that there are still research areas open to consider some questions such as the non-parametric automatic discretization approach to consider continuous streaming data under consideration of the temporal order.

referenceMentions.context: The huge amount of data is to be processed in many application areas such as scientific, financial, network monitoring, sensor data analysis [1], [2].

Many data mining algorithms can benefit from a discrete representation of the original data set as the numbers of values for a feature are many, but after the discretization, the number of discrete values is less compare to original number of values [1], [2].

Discretization has a number of advantages: Discrete features reduce memory usage and thus increase representation of the knowledge as data is simplified to understand and with this application of mining technique or knowledge retrieval methods become faster and perfect [2].

There are several ways by which discretization methods can be classified: Splitting versus Merging, Global versus Local, Supervised versus Unsupervised, Static versus Dynamic, and non-Incremental versus Incremental [2], [3], [4], [5].
